Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.html:
--- tags: [async, flutter, dart, futures, await, parallel_programming, streams] ---

Asynchronous programming allows the app to complete time-consuming tasks (writing data to a server, retrieving web data, opening then reading/writing to a file), while running other tasks concurrently.

Futures - single async operation (uploading data to the web) Streams - multiple async operations (getting GPS coordinates) Async Operations do not stop the main line of execution, allowing for other tasks to be completed in the meantime.

Dart is a single-threaded language

But, still can use async patterns. Async operations for certain tasks keeps one's app responsive.

Now referring the projects async_books

          ElevatedButton(

            child: const Text('GO!'),

            onPressed: () {

              setState(() {});

              getData().then((value) async {

                result = value.body.toString().substring(0, 450);

                setState(() {});

              }).catchError((_) {

                result = 'An error occurred';

                setState(() {});

              });

            },

          ),

In the .then() callback is when the value (Future<Response>) is received. To reiterate, the result variable is only available in the .then().

[!info]+ Isolate and Event Loops

Source - Flutter Youtube and Dart Docs - Isolate class

How does Dart simulate async despite being a single threaded language? The Isolate, an isolated Dart execution context.

All dart code runs in a isolate. Isolates have their own private chunk of memory. Meaning, it can only access classes and values from within that same isolate. Communication between isolates is done with sendPort and receivePort.

Isolates run code in its own event loop, and each event can run smaller tasks in a nested micro-task queue. Each thread is in its own isolate with its own memory and just process events.

There is no shared memory between isolates. Regarding, memory allocation and garbage collection, an isolate does not require locking because there is only one thread. So, if the event loop is not busy we know the memory is being mutated.

Event Loops

Imagine the life cycle of an application. A whole bunch of things happen. Many clicks/taps from the user, network requests and so on...

The app cannot predict when or in what order these events will happen in. It has to handle all of this with a single thread that never blocks. So it runs an event loop. The event loop thread processes events one at a time. All the high level abstractions of async programming (Futures, await, Streams, async) are built around this simple event loop.

```dart

RaisedButton(

child: Text('click me'),

onPressed: () {

final myFuture = http.get('...');

myFuture.then((response){

if(response.statusCode == 200){

print('Success!');

}

});

},

)

```

Given the above button, it is rendered and then it is waiting for the button to be pressed. When the button is pressed a tap event enters the event loops queue.

To recap, the button is waiting to be tapped and network request is waiting for a future, but these are just events in the queue.

Definitions

Concurrency versus Parallelism

Asynchronous --> Concurrency
  • Allows waiting without blocking
  • Will not create a separate thread
Isolates --> Parallelism
  • New thread spawning

Using async and await to avoid .then() callbacks

  • asunc is used to mark a method as asynchronous and it put before the body of the function.
  • await tells the framework to wait for an operation to finish and return its value.

    • Note, await must be used in an async function and if the await call another function, then that function must be labeled as async too.

Side by side comparison

.then()


Future<Response> getData(){

	String url = '...'

	return http.get(url);

}

void someMethod(){

	getData()

		.then((value) {

			//operate on value

			});

}

async/await


Future<Response> getData(){

	String url = '...'

	return http.get(url);

}

void someMethod() async {

	var value = await getData();

	//operate on value

}

Note, there is explicit method catchError for the async/await pattern, but a traditional try-catch will suffice.

Completer

Source - Flutter docs

In flutter example project asyncbookspt3

Another asynchronous technique is to use the Completer class. Completer's create Future objects that can be completed later. This allows one to control when the Future is completed. When a service does not use Futures a Completer can be used. Given the button below,


ElevatedButton(

  child: const Text('GO!'),

  onPressed: () {

	getNumber().then((value) {

	  setState(() {

		result = value.toString();

	  });

	});

  },

),

What is neat about Completer is the ability to decouple the returning of the Future and the executing of the computational time consuming task.


late Completer completingGetNumber;

Future getNumber() {

	completingGetNumber = Completer<int>();

	calculate();

	return completingGetNumber.future;

}

See late Variables The above Sets up the Completer, which creates a Completer to establish a Future that can be resolved later. But wait, doesn't calculate() initiate asynchronous work? Where is the await prefix? This is the power of the Completer class. The type of completingGetNumber.future had to be declared (could be dynamic). This is how the mechanism works...

Multiple Futures with FutureGroup

Aside, FutureGroup resides in the external package 'package:async/async.dart' while basic asynchronous utilities are in Dart built-in 'dart:async' FutureGroup returns a List in the same order in which they were added to the group.

  • add() put a Future in the collection
  • close() no more additions to this collection

    • If any of the group members error, then the whole group will return an error


onPressed: () {

		returnFG();

}

Calls the following function


void returnFG() {

	FutureGroup<int> futureGroup = FutureGroup<int>();

	futureGroup.add(returnOneAsync());

	futureGroup.add(returnTwoAsync());

	futureGroup.add(returnThreeAsync());

	futureGroup.close();

	futureGroup.future.then((List<int> value) {

	  int total = 0;

	  for (var element in value) {

		total += element;

	  }

	  setState(() {

		result = total.toString();

	  });

	});

}

Futures with StatefulWidgets

Now working with flutter example project geo_locate

A valid question should arise, where to place the getPosition() call.


  Future<Position> getPosition() async {

    await Geolocator.requestPermission();

    await Geolocator.isLocationServiceEnabled();

    Position? position = await Geolocator.getCurrentPosition();

    return position;

  }

Refer to Interactivity & Navigation for a review on State initState is only called once when the widget is loaded. Best practices recommend to to be keep initState synchronous, but a .then() is OK.

Letting Flutter handle Futures with FutureBuilder

Now working with flutter example project geolocatept2

In the scenario of retrieving some data asynchronously and updating the user interface..There is a widget for this case. Enter FutureBuilder. It automatically updates content when the Future arrives (LOL). FutureBuilder build itself based off the status of said Future allowing the setState instruction to be skipped. this programming pattern is called reactive as it is a way for the UI to react to the data in a Future. Consider the snippet below,


body: Center(

	child: FutureBuilder(

	  future: position,

	  builder: (BuildContext context, AsyncSnapshot<Position> snapshot) {

		if (snapshot.connectionState == ConnectionState.waiting) {

		  return const CircularProgressIndicator();

		} else if (snapshot.connectionState == ConnectionState.done) {

		  if (snapshot.hasError) {

			return const Text('Something terrible happened!');

		  }

		  return Text(snapshot.data.toString());

		} else {

		  return const Text('');

		}

	  },

From the above we can infer the Future is a variable called position. This variable is initialized at the top of the class with Future<Position>? position;. The declaration of this variable occurs in the initState() with a call to getPosition(). See below,


  @override

  void initState() {

    super.initState();

    position = getPosition();

  }

The FutureBuilders builder property is given an anonymous function with parameters BuildContext and AsyncSnapshot<T> where T is said Future. Checking the status of the of the AsyncSnapshotis done with its connectionState property and comparing it with the enum ConnectionState.

Asynchronous Navigation

Using Futures with Navigator, specifically turning Route in to a async function.

The scenario, a dialogue box pops up (some new screen) and its requires user input. Said again, push a new screen to the app and await the route to return some data to update the screen. An example,

  • simple button to launch a screen
  • second screen has options
  • once option is chosen the first screen will update
Working from example projection async_nav

The crux of this, await the result of the navigation. A button is pressed.


ElevatedButton(

	child: const Text('Change Color'),

    onPressed: () {

	  _navigateAndGetColor(context);

            }),

...

  Future _navigateAndGetColor(BuildContext context) async {

  color = await Navigator.push( 

  context,

  MaterialPageRoute(builder: (context) => 

    const NavigationSecond()),

        ) ?? Colors.blue;

    setState(() {});

  }

The new screen is push on the app's stack. The return value of Navigator.push is assigned to the variable color then the screen is called to be redrawn with setState. The second is a StatefulWidget with a column full of buttons like...


ElevatedButton(

  child: const Text('Red'),

  onPressed: () {

	color = Colors.red.shade700;

	Navigator.pop(context, color);

  })

Given the above code, the return value of a MaterialPageRoute should make more sense. Thanks Navigator.pop() A default value is given for color because the back arrow could be pressed on this page leaving no selection made.

await a Dialogue Window

Very similar concept to the screen example above, but instead of a new screen its just a popup window.

Working from example project asyncnavpt2

Since no new page is being rendered there is no need for a route, but just a async dialogue function that awaits a dialogue box selection. The function below is called from within a button,


_showColorDialog(BuildContext context) async {

await showDialog(

  barrierDismissible: true,

  context: context,

  builder: (_) {

	return AlertDialog(

	  content: const Text('Please choose'),

	  actions: <Widget>[

		TextButton(

			child: const Text('Red'),

			onPressed: () {

			  color = Colors.red.shade700;

			  Navigator.pop(context, color);

			}),

		TextButton(...)

		TextButton(...)

	  ],

	);

  },

).then((result) {

  if (result == null) {

	color = Colors.grey;

  } else {

	color = result;

  }



  setState(() {});

});

}

Notice, the showDialog property called barrierDismissible. This allows user to click outside the dialog box to exit the dialog box, which causes a null selection to the dialog question (user input prompt). To handle this case, the .then() chain is used.
Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.title: Async

Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.html:
--- tags: [flutter, dart, stateful, state_management] ---

Separating the UI from the Business Logic
Model-view Separation

Architecturally speaking, Models classes that deal with the data, while Views are classes that present data to the screen. A View will query a Model for meta data (size of an array). Now working with the MasterPlan project Notice how the Model is immutable. But the app seem to let the user change the text (description) and the checkbox (complete) at will. The State of the widgets is owned by the model. The UI will query the model for the most up to date data. The onChanged call back takes the new data received from the view and stores it in the model. The double dots (..) or the cascade operator allows a sequence of operations on the same object. The more verbose way of achieving the same result is. Aside, the List.from() dart method creates a new list from an existing list. A shallow copy

InheritedWidget

In contrast, StatelessWidget and StatefulWidget are widgets to configure the UI. InheritedWidget only passes data down to its children. This inheritance scheme is the bridge between view and model layers. Now working from example masterplanpt2 InheritedWidget and InheritedNotifier only pass data down lower in the tree.


class PlanProvider extends 

	InheritedNotifier<ValueNotifier<Plan>>

PlanProvider inherits from InheritedNotifier (InheritedNotifier inherits from InheritedWidget) and listens for objects that implement the Listenable interface. InheritedNotifier widgets are generic, so we need to specify the the type, ValueNotifier<Plan>. Whenever the ValueNotifier changes (the Plan changes) notifyListeners() is called to update values. Three main step to use ValueNotify:

  1. create
  2. listen
  3. update

    4. Step 1 - create


ValueNotifier<Plan> planNotifier = 

    PlanProvider.of(context);

Step 2 - listen By using the ValueListenableBuilder to automatically rebuild the UI when the value changes. Step 3 - update To update the value of ValueNotifier, change the value property and this will trigger the notifyListeners() method.

Providers

Regarding, plan_provider.dart file and the static method, ValueNotifier<Plan> Static methods can be invoked directly from the class name itself without creating an instance of it. A static field or method is shared by all instances of the class. ! is the non-null assertion operator (asserts the previous expression cannot be null).

--- Now starting from masterplanpt3

Making the app state visible across multiple screen

"Lift state up" refers to the design best practice of placing State objects as high as possible in the widget tree. To make the Master Plan project work across multiple screens the State provider need to be "lifted" closer to the root.

--- tags: [CRUD, flutter, dart] ---

Create, Read, Update, and Delete

Getting data to persist, two options:

  1. Local
  2. Remote

    3. Both require the data to be transformed in JSON first. Working with persisted is all about sending and receiving JSON. Reading data from a web service or database (our case an asset file) is usually asynchronous work. Turning Maps into a strongly typed object see note: The Dart Language, section Higher-Order Functions. In a world of messy JSON, one needs to guarantee they value of a JSON key is a String with .toString() then T.tryParse() for the expected type T and have a default coalescing value when null is found. see note: The Dart Language, section Null-Aware Coalescing Operator.


Pizza.fromJson(Map<String, dynamic> json) { 

  id = int.tryParse(json['id'].toString()) ?? 0;

  pizzaName = json['pizzaName'] != null ? json['pizzaName'].toString() : 'No name';

  description = (json['description'] != null) ? json['description'].toString() : '';

  price = double.tryParse(json['price'].toString()) ?? 0; 

  imageUrl = json['imageUrl'] ?? '';}

A common best practice when working with String is to make them of type const. const keyId = 'id'; So the .fromJson turns into, id = int.tryParse(json[keyId].toString()) ?? 0;

Persisting Data - SharePreferences

Working example project shar_pref

A quick and dirty way to store key-value pairs on disk source. Writing or reading from disk should always be done asynchronously. Note, the data being persisted:

  1. Not encrypted
  2. Not guaranteed!

    3. My thoughts, 'never use...' Upon a stateful app starting (after state is mounted - Flutter Docs), initState is called. initState is called once on start up.


@override

void initState() {

 super.initState();

 readAndWritePreference();

}



Future readAndWritePreference() async {

  SharedPreferences prefs = await SharedPreferences.getInstance();

  appCounter = prefs.getInt('appCounter') ?? 0;

  appCounter++;

  await prefs.setInt('appCounter', appCounter);

  loadedAppCounter = prefs.getInt('appCounter2') ?? 0;

setState(() {

  loadedAppCounter = loadedAppCounter;

  appCounter = appCounter;

});

}

The first time build() is called it is provided the state(context) with variables loadedAppCounter and appCounter having the values that were retrieved from the instance of SharedPreferences.

[!info]+ SharedPreference API >

|Type|Read(get)|Write(set)|

| ---- | ---- | ---- |

|int| getInt(key)|setInt(key, value)|

|double|getDouble(key)|setDouble(key, value)|

|bool|getBool(key)|setBool(key, value)|

|String|getString(key)|setString(key, value)|

|stringList|getStringList(key)|setStringList(key, value)|

An onPressed event triggers the below function


void _incrementCounter() async {

  setState(() {

    _counter++;

    loadedAppCounter++;

  });

  saveOtherLike();

  }

The member variables are incremented and then the screen is re-drawn (build() is called with an updated context variable). The call to saveOtherLike() writes the newly incremented value of loadedAppCounter is disk. This is done inside an async that returns a Future with two lines


SharedPreferences prefs = 

	await SharedPreferences.getInstance();

await prefs.setInt('appCounter2', loadedAppCounter);

Notice, how the second line is just a write. The on disk key appCounter2 is overwritten. If the key did not exist, it does now.

path_provider

Working from example project path_provide

Is a library to write files to the systems directory(temporary or documents), regardless of device. For example, in the initState() function after the super.initState() call, is a good time retrieve the device's system paths. These paths are used to write and read from. Given two state variables,


String documentsPath='';

String tempPath='';

These variables can be filled with the function call,


Future getPaths() async { 

  final docDir = await 

    getApplicationDocumentsDirectory(); 

  final tempDir = await getTemporaryDirectory();

  setState(() { 

    documentsPath = docDir.path;

    tempPath = tempDir.path; 

 }); }

No chrome web support

Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.title: Connecting Widgets.Excalidraw

Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.html:
Widget are classes that perform tasks on the user interface. Every visual item inherits from the widget class. Even the screen is a widget.

  • Text widgets display text
  • Padding widgets adds space between widgets
  • Scaffold widget provides structure for a screen

    • All widgets together form the Widget Tree (a nested tree data structure) Visual widgets come in two forms: stateless and stateful Stateless widgets are performant and immutable because there are no life cycles of states.The core of Stateless Widget the build() method. build() is called time a widget needs to be repainted (altered/changed) on the screen. When dealing with stateless widgets happens once at the start, if the device rotated and during a refresh(just like at the start) MaterialApp are the primary building block for following Google's Material Design specification. Using the MaterialApp automatically implements other design standards. Regarding Material design jargon, the MaterialApp's child is called a home and the Scaffold's child is called a body. The below show an example with the Center AspectRatio Container Scaffold widgets. Scaffold is a platform aware widget. Meaning it will change functionality based on the user's device. Using Scaffold is a good habit for design consistency.
Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.title: Everything Is A Widget

Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.html:
--- tags: dart, flutter, ui, ux, stateful --- User Interface is all the elements on the screen (images, colors, panels, text, etc) and the User Experience is what happens when the user's interact with the interface. "UI is the what and UX is the how" A stateful widget is divided into two classes: the widget and its state. Every stateful widget has a state object to help manage its life cycle (a completely separate class). As a design point, StatefulWidgets are of the few scenarios where two classes (the widget and the widget's state) should be in the same file. In StatefulWidgets, you put the build method in the State class, not in the widget Remember, StatefulWidgets are made up of two classes: the widget and its state. The widget part of the StatefulWidget does not usually do much because the data that changes is placed in the State class. All widgets are immutable, but the State object is mutable. The State object is responsible for the build method. Jargon, "dirty state" means the in the next frame it will repaint. The setState function tells Flutter that a widget needs to be repainted. Every time setState is called the build method is called. Never call build directly, rather do it through setState. The following diagram summarizes how Flutter's render loop is impacted by setState Note, that complex operations should not be performed in the setState function, but just the final value assignment.

State Life Cycle

Unlike StatelessWidget, which has nothing more than a build method. StatefulWidgets have a life cycle of methods that are called in a specific order:

  • initState
  • didChangeDependencies
  • didUpdateWidget
  • build (required)
  • reassemble
  • deactivate
  • dispose

[!flut]- initState

- used to initialize any non-final state in the class

- kinda like a constructor

- This method is called after the constructor but before it is added to the widget tree.

[!flut]- didChangeDependencies

- this method is called after initState, but has access to the BuildContext

- Useful for any set up work that requires context

[!flut]- build

- required

- Identical to the StatelessWidget version

- This defines and returns the widget's tree (creating the UI)

[!flut]- dispose

- The cleanup method

- Called when the State object is removed from the widget tree

- One must explicitly release finished resources

Buttons

Flutter has several aesthetically different buttons

  • ElevatedButton
  • TextButton
  • IconButton
  • FloatingActionButton
  • OutlinedButton
  • DropDownButton
  • CupertinoButton

Scrolling

ListView has scrolling builtin by default when its widgets extend past the screen. A scrolling widget needs to know their parent’s constraints to activate scrolling, putting scroll widgets inside widgets with unbounded constraints can cause Flutter to throw errors.

Constraints go down -> Sizes go up

More in Layout In Flutter there’s a rule: “Constraints go down. Sizes go up.”. This means that:

  • Parent widgets pass down constraints to their children. Constraints are passed in a BoxContraints object, that includes minimum and maximum values for the width and height of the children.
  • Children widgets determine their size and then pass the information back up to the parent widget

    • If you place a scrolling widget inside a Flex widget (like Row or Column), which is pretty common, just don’t forget to always wrap the scrolling content in Expanded or Flexible first. This error means that you have an unbounded scrolling widget

Handling Large Datasets with ListView (Scrolling)

The problem is handling large amount of data in a scrolling widget. We know only a certain amounts of views (widgets that hold data) fit on any screen at once. The trick is to, recycling views with new data instead of creating new views. The itemCount property to the ListView.builder() lets Flutter know how long the list is. duh! The itemBuilder property and its value (a closure) help with performance to limit the creation of Elements and RenderObjects. itemBuilder is using deferred rendering to create only what it needs and manage a subset of the total widgets. The scroll tree is limited to only what is needed. Flutter will continuously call itemBuilder with an updated index as the user scrolls. Assuming the size of the viewport is constant, the programmer only manages the fixed number of visible entries.  itemExtent property is a way to supply a fixed height to all the items in ListView. Instead of letting the widget figure out its own height based on the content, using itemExtent will enforce a fixed height and leads to performance benefits.  ScrollController object allows programmers to interact with a ListView from outside the build methods.  ```dart scrollController.animateTo( itemHeight * laps.length, duration: Duration(milliseconds: 500), curve: Curves.easeIn, );




`itemHeight * laps.length,` this argument dictates where to scroll to. 

Since, there we set items to have a fixed height we can calculate how far to automatically scroll. 



`duration: Duration(milliseconds: 500),` dictates how long it will take to scroll to the calculated position. 



`curve: Curves.easeIn,` how (animate) to get there



### Working with `TextField`s

`TextField` has a subclass called `TextFormField` for text fields that interact with each other. `TextField`s are platform aware widgets.

`validator` on failure will return a string and on success return `null`.

`Form` widget can wrap many `TextFields` and is a non-rendering widget. `Form` can contain non-`TextFields`, but keeps track which ones `null`(valid). If all validator functions wrapped in `Form` return `null` then the entire `Form` is valid. 

`GlobalKey` used to get access to the form’s state class from outside the `build` method. `GlobalKey`'s uniquely identify elements. While `BuildContext` is an object that can find **parents**  in the widget tree, `GlobalKey`'s are objects that you use to retrieve a **child** widget tree. (_GlobalKey is a complex topic. This is a brief, crude intro_). In short, with the key, you can retrieve the Form’s state. The `FormState` class has a public method called `validate` that will call the validator on all its children.

### Navigating to the next screen

**Now working from stopwatch part 2 project**

Within `MaterialApp` a class called `Navigator` manages screens. The `Navigator` class abstracts screens to the concept of `Routes`. 

Regarding a login event, once a use logs successfully the back button to return to the login screen should be inaccessible.

Navigator.of(context).pushReplacement( MaterialPageRoute( builder: (_) => StopWatch(name: name, email: email), ), );


`Navigator`'s function as a stack. `Routes` can be pushed onto and popped off of.The above snippet will remove the `Route` (screen) from the `Navigator` stack.

`pushNamed` does pop then push of the current stack

### Presenting Bottom Sheet

**Now working from stopwatch part 3 project**

A bottom sheet is like a footer that be animated. It can temporarily or permanently appear after an event.  

The app's widget looks like.

![[widgetTree.png]]

Bottom sheets are partial routes. They use the closest `Scaffold` by using the `of-context` to find it. The above graphic shows the `BuildContext` we do **not** want. The error message `No Scaffold Widget found` will be triggered when the nearest `Scaffold` is too far up in the tree to be used. The solution is to use a `BuildContext` lower in the tree. Wrapping the button (that uses the bottom sheet) in the `Builder` widget will solve this. 

![[bottomSheetBuilder.png]]

The above snippet demonstrate how to create a `BuildContext` closer to the button. 

![[widgetTreeWithBuilder.png]]

###### Persistent controllers

![[bottomSheetController.png]]

The `showBottomSheet` method returns a **persistent controller** used to manipulate them.
Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.title: Interactivity & Navigation

Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.html:
--- tags: [flutter, layout, ui, ] ---

Important Layout details

Constraints Got Down -> Sizes Go Up

Article Highlights:

  • A widget gets its own constraints from its parent. A constraint is just a set of 4 doubles: a minimum and maximum width, and a minimum and maximum height.
  • Then the widget goes through its own list of children. One by one, the widget tells its children what their constraints are (which can be different for each child), and then asks each child what size it wants to be.
  • Then, the widget positions its children (horizontally in the x axis, and vertically in the y axis), one by one.
  • And, finally, the widget tells its parent about its own size (within the original constraints, of course).

    • Flutter’s layout engine is designed to be a one-pass process. This means that Flutter lays out its widgets very efficiently, but does result in a few limitations:

  • A widget can decide its own size only within the constraints given to it by its parent. This means a widget usually can’t have any size it wants.
  • A widget can’t know and doesn’t decide its own position in the screen, since it’s the widget’s parent who decides the position of the widget.
  • Since the parent’s size and position, in its turn, also depends on its own parent, it’s impossible to precisely define the size and position of any widget without taking into consideration the tree as a whole.
  • If a child wants a different size from its parent and the parent doesn’t have enough information to align it, then the child’s size might be ignored. Be specific when defining alignment.

    • Constraints go down. Sizes go up. Positions are set by parents Positions are set by parents Sizes go up Constraints go down

Same article two different sources Source - 'The Advanced Layout Rule Even Beginners Must Know' Source - 'Understanding Constraints'

wiki: Interactivity & Navigation#Scrolling#Constraints go down -> Sizes go up

Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.title: Layout

Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.html:
--- tags:

  • flutter
  • dart
  • layout
  • assets
  • widget_tree

    • ---

Row and Column Widgets

  • A Row can be inserted into a Column and vice versa

    • Both have the properties CrossAxisAlignment and MainAxisAlignment

  • both these properties are abstractions of x y axis and tweaking these values will alter the layout. Notice, the MainAxisAligment for Column widgets is vertically down and Row is horizontal across. Vice versa for the CrossAxisAlignment parameter.

    • the only real difference between is their default orientation axis they start laying out children

Stack Widget

  • expects the use of Align, Transform, and Positioned to form the layout.

    • Note use SizedBox over Container in most cases The developer tools in the browser has a show guide lines options to draw rendering reference lines.

Flexible Interfaces account for myriad device layouts
Developing Proportional Widgets with Flexible and Expanded Widgets

Styling

The ThemeData is a normal class that stores themes and sub-themes. Theme.of.(context) is an inherited widget meaning, all the descendants of the Theme widget get its defined theme(style). Each widget travels up the widget tree until a Theme widget is found. Can be used like... color: Theme.of(context).cardColor, style: Theme.of(context).textTheme.headlineMedium, `style: Theme.of(context).textTheme.headlineMedium,


color: selected

  ? null

  : Theme.of(context)

	  .textTheme

	  .titleMedium

	  ?.color

	  ?.withOpacity(0.5),

                  ```

The variable `context` of type `BuildContext` is the only object that is aware of the underlying widget tree.

Many widgets are _theme aware_, meaning, by default the widget references it's parent theme properties. 



Flutter places assets into a special archive called the _asset bundle_ that apps read from at runtime
Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.title: Mastering The Widget Tree

Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.html:
--- tags: [createproject,fluttercommandline, flutterbuildproject, compile, recompile, hotreload, folder_structure, dart, flutter] ---

Create Project at Command line

$ flutter create hello_flutter When developing with no internet access use $ flutter create --offline hello_flutter For command line help by command


$ flutter <command> --help

$ flutter create --help
Once a project is created there are several 'targets'
  • Connecting a device to your computer
  • Starting a simulator/emulator
  • running the app on a web browser
  • running the app on your desktop
Emulator versus Device

Devices run in the developments native environment Emulators simulate alien environments On my MacBook, iOS and Android need to emulated, while devices are macOS desktop applications and Chrome applications are native

Run Application in Chrome

$ flutter run -d chrome

Configure for Web Deployment

$ flutter build web

Language choice

iOS went from Objective C to Swift Android went from Java to Kotlin

Folder Structure

android, ios, linux, web, and windows folders are created from the from the flutter create project_name command. The ios and android folder be opened in Xcode and Android Studio, respectively, and will run like normal native apps

Build

Dart and Flutter support both Just-in-Time (JIT) and Ahead-of-Time (AOT) compilation.

JIT
  • compile the source code of the app and translate into machine code during execution
  • makes for faster development/testing because the code can be recompiled while the app is running
AOT
  • code is compiled before program execution
  • this builds a machine code executable that can run the target machine and lead to better performance
Flutter uses JIT for debug builds and AOT for release builds

All artifacts from the compilation process are placed in the build folder. Add this folder to the .gitignore

Hot Reload - Refreshing without recompiling

This is called a stateful hot reload, which is that Flutter can inject new code into your app while it is running without loosing your position (state) in your app

Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.title: Stream Controller.Excalidraw

Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.html:
--- tags: [flutter, dart, state, statemanagement, future, async] --- In contrast, Future can be used to await a single object, while, Stream is the class allows continuous flow. A data stream is listened_ to and waits for new data. Like a Future, a Stream can emit datum and errors.

Working from example project colorstreambg

When creating a data stream the function signature is such, Stream<T> myFunc() async*. The asterisks and the return type are emblematic of a Stream. Conceptually, the main difference between a Future and a Stream is the number events being returned. These Stream functions are called generators. Stream.periodic() creates the event emitting Stream, which is prefaced with a yield*. The period(interval) in which the Stream is spits out data specified in the first parameter to Stream.periodic(). The second parameter to Stream.periodic() is the total count of interval units (time) that have elapsed.


Stream<List<dynamic>> getColors() async* {

  yield* Stream.periodic(const 

    Duration(milliseconds: 100), (int t) {

	  int index = t % colors.length;

	  return [colors[index], t];

	});

}

Above is a fully functioning Stream. Now we need to listen to it. First, we need to initialize the stream once.


Color bgColor = Colors.blueGrey;

late ColorStream colorStream;

late int num;



@override

void initState() {

	super.initState();

	colorStream = ColorStream();

	num = -1;

	changeColor();

}

Conceptually, we need to wait for flow of data and process it accordingly.


changeColor() async { 

  await for (var eventColor in 

    colorStream.getColors()) { 

      setState(() { 

        bgColor = eventColor; 

        });

} }

Alternatively,


colorStream.getColors().listen((eventColor) { 

  setState(() { 

    bgColor = eventColor; 

  }); });
await for vs .listen()

Source - Dart Docs .listen() - Low level method. All other Stream methods depend on it. await for - this is syntactic sugar around .listen().

Controller and Sinks

StreamControllers are for Stream management and their property sinks are used to insert events. Streams can be envisioned as a one-way funnel. The creation of a StreamController and a helper function to add to the controller's sink property.


final StreamController<int> controller = 

  StreamController<int>();



void addNumberToSink(int newNumber) {

  controller.sink.add(newNumber);

}

The function addNumberToSink is used to insert (integers, in this case) into a Stream by means of a sink. The orchestration is assisted by class member variables.


 int lastNumber = 0;

 late StreamController numberStreamController;

 late NumberStream numberStream;

The two undeclared variables will be set in the initState() ``` dart @override void initState() { numberStream = NumberStream(); numberStreamController = numberStream.controller; Stream stream = numberStreamController.stream; stream.listen((event) { setState(() { lastNumber = event; }); }); super.initState(); }


![[Stream_controller.excalidraw|555]]

Throw an error is done with,

`numberStream.addError()`

And catching it done by,

stream.listen((event) { setState(() { lastNumber = event; }); }).onError((error) { setState(() { astNumber =-1; }); });


##### Manipulating emitted `Stream` data

Using `StreamTransformer` allows an explicit time and place to modify stream data. 

###### Working from example project stream_trans

Implementing, first, declare a member variable.

`late StreamTransformer tx;`

In the `initState()` configure a `StreamTransformer`,

tx = StreamTransformer<int, int>.fromHandlers( handleData: (value, sink) { sink.add(value * 10); }, handleError: (error, trace, sink) { sink.add(-1); }, handleDone: (sink) => sink.close());


Wrangling the emitted stream data with a trivial operation. 

###### Working from example project stream_sub

When `listen` is called on a `Stream` a `StreamSubscription` is returned. When subscriptions are explicitly created one can specify properties like `onDone`,  `onError`, or `cancelOnError`. 

#### Broadcast `Stream`s

Multiple listeners on the same `Stream`.

###### Working from example project stream_broad

Many subscribers to one broadcast stream. 

### Reactive interfaces with `StreamBuilder` 

`StreamBuilder` is an efficient way to rebuild widgets on the screen. Traditionally, a `setState()` will trigger a re-build() of an entire widget tree. Sometime, we only want to re-build certain widgets on the tree. **Only widgets contained in `StreamBuilder` are re-drawn**. 

###### Working from example project streambuilder_app

#### BLoC Design Pattern

_everything is a stream of events_ in **B**usiness **L**ogic **C**omponent pattern. Separating the source data(HTTP data retrieval or JSON from a Database) from the user interface. 

###### Working from example project streambuilder_app2

3 Concepts to adhere to:

1. Receive `Stream` (source data)

2. Transform data

3. Return `Stream` to subscribers 

![[streamBuilder.excalidraw|555]]

10 tips for BLoC

1. Create a class that will serve as the BLoC.

2. In the class, declare the data that needs to be updated in the app.

3. Set `StreamControllers`.

4. Create the getters for streams and sinks.

5. Add the logic of the BLoC.

6. Add a constructor in which you’ll set the data.

7. Listen to changes.

8. Set a `dispose` method.

9. From the UI, create an instance of the BLoC.

10. Use `StreamBuilder` to build the widgets that will use the BLoC data.

11. Add events to the sink for any changes to the data (if required).

Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.html:
--- tags: [dart, const, final, var, variables, type, types, dynamic, mutable, variables, immutable, variables, OOP, ObjectOrientedProgramming, records, switch_statement, class, closure, inheritance] --- A language made by Google in 2011 meant to supplant Javascript. Conservative in nature.

  • strongly typed language
  • support asynchronous programming
  • uses both JIT and AOT
  • Since Dart 3 it is now soundly null safe

    • ---

Examples ran in DartPad.dev


void main() {

  variablePlayground(); 



}

void variablePlayground() {

 basicTypes();

}

void basicTypes() {

 int four = 4;

 double pi = 3.14;

 num someNumber = 24601;

 bool yes = true;

 bool no = false;

 int? nothing; 

 print(four);

 print(pi); 

 print(someNumber);

 print(yes);

 print(no);

 print(nothing == null);

}

The above outputs...


4

3.14

24601

true

false

true

Dynamic types are sort of a 'get out of jail free card' that can be anything and should NOT be used.


void untypedVariables() {

 dynamic something = 14.2;

 print(something.runtimeType); //outputs 'double'

}
Similar type inferring can be done with var but NOT exactly the same

void typeInterpolation() {

 var anInteger = 15;

 var aDouble = 27.6;

 var aBoolean = false;

 print(anInteger.runtimeType);

 print(anInteger);

 print(aDouble.runtimeType);

 print(aDouble);

 print(aBoolean.runtimeType);

 print(aBoolean);

}

outputs


int

15

double

27.6

bool

false

In the above snippet the variable anInteger is only mutable within the bounds of the int type.

Immutable variables

final and const must be determined at compile time. For example, a const variable cannot be have the value of DateTime.now() since the date can only determined at runtime. final variables have a little leeway. Though, they can only be assigned once, if the final variable is assigned to an object then the value of the variable can change by adjusting the fields of that object. const does not have this flexibility. Generally, it is a good idea to favor immutable over mutable because mutability is more likely to lead to errors and immutable variables are faster.

Strings and string interpolation


final age = 42;

final howOld = 'I am $age ${age == 1 ? 'year' : 'years'} old.'; print(howOld);

In the snippet above, placing simple variables in a string is done with $ but the brackets are necessary if you want an expression to be computed in the string.


final rawString = r'I want to show an escape \ character';

The r'..' raw string is used to print escape characters. Dart also has a StringBuffer which is like Java's string builder. The functionality is an incremental string concatenator. StringBuffer as better performance than normal string interpolation.


List fruits = ['Strawberry', 'Coconut', 

			   'Orange', 'Mango', 'Apple'];

StringBuffer buffer = StringBuffer();

for (String fruit in fruits) { 

	buffer.write(fruit);

	buffer.write(' ');

	 } 

print (buffer.toString());

	  // prints: Strawberry Coconut Orange Mango Apple

Functions

Normal structure


int factorial(int number){

	if (number <= 0){

	return 1;

	}

	return number * factorial(number - 1)

}

Optional positional parameters are wrapped in square brackets. The ? after the type tells the Dart compiler that the parameter itself can be null.

Null-Aware Coalescing Operator

```dart void unnamed([String? name, int? age]) { final actualName = name ?? 'Unknown'; final actualAge = age ?? 0; print('$actualName is $actualAge years old.'); }


In the above snippet, the double `??` is the **null-aware coalescing operator** which is a quick to check if a value is null then provide a default value if it is.

**Named Optional Parameters** with curly brackets `{}`. When calling a function with named parameters you **NEED** to specify the parameter name but the parameter list can be in any order.

void named({String? greeting, String? name}) { final actualGreeting = greeting ?? 'Hello'; final actualName = name ?? 'Mystery Person'; print('$actualGreeting, $actualName!'); }


**BOTH** optional parameters and optional named parameter support default values. If a function is called with one of these styles then `null` will not be used in preference to their default value.

In the below example, there is a mix of both **required** and **named optional**.

String duplicate(String name, {int times = 1}) { final merged = StringBuffer(name); for (var i = 1; i < times; i++) { merged.write(' $name'); } return merged.toString();}


For completeness the above is called like 

`duplicate('Mikey', times: 3);`

# Name Parameters make readable code

When a function does not have a return type or functional parameter, the **dynamic** type is used but this style should be avoided.

### Functions as a variable -> Closures

Closures are known as first-class functions. As a language feature they emerged form lambda calculus. Closure allow functions to be passed as parameters to other functions. To add a closure to a function, define another function signature inside a function.

void callbackExample( void Function(String value) callback ) { callback('Hello Callback'); }

void printSomething(String value) { print(value); }


The above closure the function is initiated by 

`callbackExmaple(printSomething)`

The variable `callback` has a value of the function `printSomething` 

The above snippet is defines an inline closure. A less verbose way is to the type alias called `typedef`. It makes the function signature cleaner.

typedef CallBack = void Functions();

void callbackExample(CallBack callback ) { callback('Hello Callback'); }


Another example...

typedef NumberGetter = int Function();

int powerOfTwo(NumberGetter getter) { return getter() * getter(); }


The above code is activated by the below snippet. Notice the *rocket notation* for single line functions.

int getFour() => 4; final squared = powerOfTwo(getFour);


#### Switch Statements

int dayOfWeek = 7; //String myDay = getDay(dayOfWeek); var myDay = switch (dayOfWeek) { 1 => 'Monday', 2 => 'Tuesday', 3 => 'Wednesday', 4 => 'Thursday', 5 => 'Friday', 6 => 'Saturday', 7 => 'Sunday' , _ => 'Invalid day' //Default value }; print(myDay);


### Records

Since Dart 3, the **record expression** is used to hold custom data like ...

var person = (name: 'Clark', age: 42); print (person.name);


In the above case, the variable `person` is the **record expression**. These are an immutable set of fields. 

The below functions `getPeron` returns a **record** which is similar to a tuple.

void main() { var (String name, int age) = getPerson( {'name': 'Clark', 'age': 42}); print('$name is $age years old.'); } (String, int) getPerson(Map<String, dynamic> json) { return (json['name'] as String, json['age'] as int); }


### Classes

Not much different from other [[Programming Paradigms|Object Oriented languages]]. Classes are used to make custom types.

class Name { final String first; final String last; Name(this.first, this.last); @override String toString() { return '$first $last'; } }


Now using the above and class through inheritance.

class OfficialName extends Name { // Private properties begin with an underscore final String title; // You can add colons after constructor // to parse data or delegate to super OfficialName(this.title, String first, String last) : super(first, last); @override String toString() { return '$_title. ${super.toString()}'; } }


How the above is used

final name = OfficialName('Mr', 'Clark', 'Kent'); final message = name.toString(); print(message)


A note about the *constructor shorthand* 

`const Name(this.first, this.last) : super(first, last):`

This allows member variable assignment by using `this` with dot notation.

#### Building Block of Object Oriented Programming

###### 3 keywords for building relationships

1. `extends` -> _class inheritance_

2. `implements` -> _interface conformance_

3. `with` -> _apply mixin_

`extends` adds functionality to the super class. 1 extends per class

`implements` **all classes are implicit interfaces**. Does not inherit any code just a contract to write a the same function signatures. Infinite implements can be applied to a class.

`with` uses `mixin`s for multiple class hierarchies. When defining a `mixin`, `extends` cannot be used. A `mixin` declaration defines a `mixin`. A `class` declaration defines a [class](https://dart.dev/language/classes). A `mixin class` declaration defines a class that is usable as both a regular class and a `mixin`, with the same name and the same type.

##### Spread Operator 

A brief way to add multiple values into a collection.

var list = [1, 2, 3]; var list2 = [0, ...list]; assert(list2.length == 4);


If `list` variable could be **null** use the **null-aware spread operator**

var list2 = [0, ...?list];


#### Higher-Order Functions 

Functions that take one or more functions as arguments or return a function.

Given data of this form. The goal is to turn this mapping into a strongly typed object.

List<Map> data = [ {'first': 'Nada', 'last': 'Mueller', 'age': 10}, ... ];


We will use the previous seen `Name` class

class Name { final String first; final String last; Name(this.first, this.last); @override String toString() { return '$first $last'; } }


We will use `map` function to transform the data into a new form. From a `Map` type to encapsulating in a class (object) called `Name`.

Imagine the `data` variable above is a global variable and is in scope of the function `mapping()` below.

List<Name> mapping() { // Transform the data // from raw maps to a strongly typed model final names = data.map<Name>((Map rawName) { final first = rawName['first']; final last = rawName['last']; return Name(first, last); }).toList(); return names; }


The above snippet can also be done with a loop below. Notice how the mapping takes care of the looping and the adding to the list.

final names = <Name>[]; for (Map rawName in data) { final first = rawName['first']; final last = rawName['last']; final name = Name(first, last); names.add(name); }


Now that the `map` function's internals are understood there is even a more concise way translate the data variable of type `Map` into a strongly typed object.

final names = data.map<Name>( (raw) => Name(raw['first'], raw['last']), ).toList();


Now that data is properly formatted we can sort by the object's property (last name). Notice no new variable is created after `sort` is called therefore, **in place sort**

void sorting() { final names = mapping(); // Sort the list by last name names.sort((a, b) => a.last.compareTo(b.last)); print(''); print('Alphabetical List of Names'); names.forEach(print); }


Pull a subset of data from the list of Name objects.

void filtering() { final names = mapping(); final onlyMs = names.where( (name) => name.last.startsWith('M')); print(''); print('Filters name list by M'); onlyMs.forEach(print); }


Calculate average age. `reduce` works like a running sum expression

``` dart 

void reducing() {

// Merge an element of the data together 

final allAges = data.map<int>((person) => person['age']);

final total = allAges.reduce((total, age) => total + age);

final average = total / allAges.length;

print('The average age is $average'); }

Flattening a multi-dimensional list to 1 dimensional.


final matrix = [

  [1, 2, 3],

  [4, 5, 6],

  [-7, -8, -9],

];

final linear = matrix.expand<int>((row) => row);

(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, -7, -8, -9) Quick print of an iterable


// Instead of doing this 

data.forEach((value) { print(value); });

// We can do this 

data.forEach(print);

Brevity by chaining higher-order functions ``` dart final names = data .map<Name>( (raw) => Name(raw['first'], raw['last'])) .where((name) => name.last.startsWith('M')) .where((name) => name.first.length > 5) .toList(growable: false);


Iterables are _lazy_  so each high-order function is cached and only ran once the `.toList()` is called. The above is a single pass algorithm. By default in dart all lists are growable. Here, we declare the list cannot get any bigger than its initial size.



#### fold()

[Source - Dart API](https://api.dart.dev/stable/1.10.1/dart-core/List/fold.html)

dynamic fold( initialValue, dynamic combine(previousValue, E element) )


Reduces a collection to a single value by iteratively combining each element of the collection with an existing value.

Uses `initialValue` as the initial value, then iterates through the elements and updates the value with each element using the `combine` function, as if by:

var value = initialValue; for (E element in this) { value = combine(value, element); } return value;


Example of calculating the sum of an iterable:

iterable.fold(0, (prev, element) => prev + element);


##### First class functions versus higher-order functions 

- A first-class function can be treated as a value: it can be assigned to a variable, passed as an argument, or returned as a value.

- A higher-order function takes one or more functions as arguments or returns a function as a result.

This means that first-class functions can be treated as values, and higher-order functions take or return functions as input or output.

#### The Builder Pattern

used when constructors get too large. The below will incrementally build out the object with one constructor call at a time.

class UrlBuilder { String? scheme; String? host; String? path; UrlBuilder setScheme(String value) { scheme = value; return this; } UrlBuilder setHost(String value) { host = value; return this; } UrlBuilder setPath(String value) { path = value; return this; } String build() { assert(scheme != null); assert(host != null); assert(path != null); return '$scheme://$host/$path'; } } void main() { final url = UrlBuilder() .setScheme('https') .setHost('dart.dev') .setPath('/guides/language/language-tour#cascade-notation-') .build(); print(url); }


The above is verbose and unnecessary 

``` dart 

class UrlBuilder { 

  String scheme = '';

  String host = ''; 

  List<String> routes = []; 

  @override 

  String toString() { 

    final paths = [host, if (routes != []) ...routes]; 

    final path = paths.join('/'); 

    return '$scheme://$path'; } }

To populate the above class use the Cascade operator


final url = UrlBuilder() 

	..scheme = 'https' 

	..host = 'dart.dev' 

	..routes = [ 'guides',

				 'language',

				  'language-tour#cascade-notation', ];

	 print(url);

Another Cascade example


final numbers = [342, 23423, 53, 232, 534]; 

numbers.insert(0, 10);

numbers.sort((a, b) => a.compareTo(b));

The above becomes this with Cascade


final numbers = [342, 23423, 53, 232, 534] 

	..insert(0, 10) 

	..sort((a, b) => a.compareTo(b));
Extensions

Extensions allow methods and properties to be adding to existing classes without modifying the original class. Especially useful when the class cannot be changed...


extension StringExtensions on String {

  bool toBool() { return isNotEmpty; } 

  }

Sound Null Safety

Generally, variables that have no value are null but with null safety variables cannot be assigned to a null value BUT the use of null can be beneficial so now null values have to be explicitly allowed. To force a Uncaught TypeError use the !


void main() {

 int? someNumber;

 increaseValue(someNumber!);

}

void increaseValue(int value) {

 value++; 

 print (value);

}

--- tags: [dart, flutter, test, testing, unit_test] ---

Write a test first!

Given the flutter create project_name basic template with a simple modification to change the color and font size based on the parity of button clicks

Below is the full app the test file

import 'package:flutter/material.dart';



void main() {

  runApp(const MyApp());

}



class MyApp extends StatelessWidget {

  const MyApp({super.key});



  @override

  Widget build(BuildContext context) {

    return MaterialApp(

      title: 'Flutter Demo',

      theme: ThemeData(

        colorScheme: ColorScheme.fromSeed(

	        seedColor: Colors.deepPurple),

        useMaterial3: true,

      ),

      home: const MyHomePage(

	      title: 'Flutter Demo Home Page'),

    );

  }

}



class MyHomePage extends StatefulWidget {

  const MyHomePage({super.key, required this.title});



  final String title;



  @override

  State<MyHomePage> createState() => _MyHomePageState();

}



class _MyHomePageState extends State<MyHomePage> {

  int _counter = 0;

  Color color = Colors.red;

  double font_size = 18;



  void _incrementCounter() {

    setState(() {

      _counter++;

      if (isEven(_counter)) {

        color = Colors.red;

        font_size = 28;

      } else {

        color = Colors.green;

        font_size = 18;

      }

    });

  }



  @override

  Widget build(BuildContext context) {

    return Scaffold(

      appBar: AppBar(

        backgroundColor: Theme.of(context).

	        colorScheme.inversePrimary,

        title: Text(widget.title),

      ),

      body: Center(

        child: Column(

          mainAxisAlignment: MainAxisAlignment.center,

          children: <Widget>[

            Text(

            'You have pushed the button this many times:',

                style: TextStyle(

                  color: color,

                  fontSize: font_size,

                )),

            Text(

              '$_counter',

              style: Theme.of(context)

	              .textTheme.headlineMedium,

            ),

          ],

        ),

      ),

      floatingActionButton: FloatingActionButton(

        onPressed: _incrementCounter,

        tooltip: 'Increment',

        child: const Icon(Icons.add),

      ), // This trailing comma makes auto-formatting nicer for build methods.

    );

  }

}



bool isEven(int number) {

  if (number % 2 == 0) {

    return true;

  } else {

    return false;

  }

}

from lib/test/unit_test.dart


import 'package:flutter_test/flutter_test.dart';

import 'package:hello_flutter/main.dart';



void main() {

  test('Is Even', () {

    bool result = isEven(12);

    expect(result, true);

    result = isEven(123);

    expect(result, false);

  });

}

syntax for test(test_name, function) The above test is bad form because tests should only test one thing at a time. Better style below


void main() {

  test('Is Even', () {

    bool result = isEven(12);

    expect(result, true);

  });

  test('Is Odd', () {

    bool result = isEven(123);

    expect(result, false);

  });

}

Purposefully fail. From the test named Is Odd change expect(result, True);


$ flutter test

  Expected: <true>

    Actual: <false>

  

  package:matcher                                     expect

  package:flutter_test/src/widget_tester.dart 454:18  expect

  test/unit_test.dart 11:5                            main.<fn>

  



To run this test again: /Users/g_joss/Developer/flutter/bin/cache/dart-sdk/bin/dart test /Users/g_joss/Documents/Computation/flutter/cook_book_Alessandria/hello_flutter/test/unit_test.dart -p vm --plain-name 'Is Odd'

00:09 +2 -1: Some tests failed.

Flutter tests have a grouping functionality to group similar tests.


void main() {

  group('Iseven group', () {

    test('Is Even', () {

      bool result = isEven(12);

      expect(result, true);

    });

    test('Is Odd', () {

      bool result = isEven(123);

      expect(result, true);

    });

  });

}

Computing/web_dev/Flutter/Flutter_Cookbo.html:
--- tags: [dart, dartlanguage, variables, nullsafety, nullable, late, final, const, lazyintialization] --- variable_ - a user defined symbols that hold a reference to some value. Aside, Variable Declaration versus Initialization var

  • stores mutable references
Null Safety

Is a best practice that prevents the error(s) of 'unintentionally' accessing a variable set to null

  • this error is called a 'null dereferenced error'

    • Dart compiler detects the possibility of the null dereferenced errors at compile time Source - Dart Docs

Nullability in 3 steps

  1. Must be use ?

    2. ``dart String? name // Nullable type. Can be null` or string.

String name // Non-nullable type. Cannot be null but can be string.


2. Variable must be initialized before declaration

3. You cannot access properties or call methods on an expression with nullable types 

##### `late` 

Use cases for `late` variables

- Declaring a non-nullable variable that is initialized after its declaration

late String description;

void main() { description = 'Feijoada!'; print(description); }


- Lazy initializing of a variable

In the following example if the variable `temperature` is never used then the function `readThermometer` is never called

// This is the program's only call to readThermometer(). late String temperature = readThermometer(); // Lazily initialized.




#### `final` and `const`

variables that never change. **Immutable** 

`const` 'compile-time constants' that will optimized runtime performance by storing the value in memory.

Another way to say it, `const` variables must be determined at compile time

###### `const` *variables* and their *values*

var foo = const []; final bar = const []; const baz = []; // Equivalent to const []


regarding the `foo` variable,  notice it has a `const` value, but `foo` itself is not a `const` variable. Therefore...

foo = [1, 2, 3]; // is valid baz = [42]; // Error: Constant variables can't be assigned a value.

--- tags: [flutter, channels, dart, framework] ---

  1. User Interface Framework
  2. Collection of Tools

    3. Flutter is attempting, "one codebase multi-platform" Flutter UIs area created by combining and nesting widgets

Channels
  • Flutter segments it development streams
  • Each channel represents different level of stability of the flutter framework
  • As new features are being developed they are first released to the master channel and as the new features stabilize they great promoted to the beta channel and then finally to the stable channel

$ flutter channel

Flutter channels:

  master (latest development branch, for contributors)

  main (latest development branch, follows master channel)

  beta (updated monthly, recommended for experienced users)

* stable (updated quarterly, for new users and for production app releases)

--- tags: [dart, flutter, widgets, class] ---

A class that inherits (extends) from a widget class


class GradientContainer extends StatelessWidget {

	const GradientContainer({super.key});

	@override

	Widget build(context) {}

}

Required

  1. class constructor defined
    • const GradientContainer({super.key}); assigning required variable to/in the parent class
      1. build must return a Widget
        • Widget build(context) is the driver function of a given widget

Linking widgets across files, see example below

  • SimpleCustomWidget

Passing Data between widgets

  • PassingData

Alternative ways to declare the a class' constructor
  1. 'Classical way'

class GradientContainer extends StatelessWidget {

  const GradientContainer(

  this.color1, this.color2, {super.key}

  );

//... cut off for brevity

The use...


//... cut off for brevity 

      home: Scaffold(

        body: GradientContainer(

          Color.fromARGB(255, 33, 5, 109),

          Color.fromARGB(255, 68, 21, 149),

        ),

//... cut off for brevity
  1. Require named arguments inside the {}

class GradientContainer extends StatelessWidget {

  const GradientContainer(

      {super.key, 

      required this.color1, required this.color2}

  );

//... cut off for brevity

the use...


//... cut off for brevity 

      home: Scaffold(

        body: GradientContainer(

          color1: Color.fromARGB(255, 33, 5, 109),

          color2: Color.fromARGB(255, 68, 21, 149),

        ),

//... cut off for brevity
  1. Named Constructor function. There can be many constructor functions per class

class GradientContainer extends StatelessWidget {

  const GradientContainer(

	  this.color1, this.color2, {super.key}

  );



  const GradientContainer.purp({super,key})

	  : color1 = Color.deepPurple,

	  : color2 = Color.indigo,

//... cut off for brevity

the use...


//... cut off for brevity 

      home: Scaffold(

        body: GradientContainer.purp(),

//... cut off for brevity

Note, all of the above constructors are const. Meaning, only one global instance of this object is created and no field values can be changed during the life cycle of the object. Also, note, all instance of super.key are in curly brackets {} meaning it is an optional parameter. super refers to the parent class and key is like a uuid.

---

Container

Is rendered as a box with many styling options. The child of each Container widget is the Padding widget, but The widget Container has a padding (lowercase 'p') property the essentially does the same thing.


@override 

Widget build(BuildContext context) { 

	return Container( 

		color: Colors.green,

		child: Padding( 

			padding: const EdgeInsets.all(40),

			child: Container( 

				color: Colors.purple,

				child: Padding(

					padding: const EdgeInsets.all(50.0),

					child: Container(

						color: Colors.blue,

						 ), ), ), ), ); }

This scheme is also acceptable. Using the Container's property to achieve padding.


child: Container(

	padding: EdgeInsets.all(24),

	color: Colors.blue,

	child: ...)

Containers provide their own transforms, paddings and margins. Also, two decorations: background and foreground decoration.

Scaffold

The root of the screen. Widgets that do not begin with Scaffold are intended to be components used to compose screens. This is a platform aware widget.

Center

Horizontally and vertically centers

AspectRatio

Tries the largest width possible in its context, and then set the height by applying the chosen ratio to the width. For example, an AspectRatio of 1 will set the height equal to the width.

Computing/web_dev/JsDefinitiveGuide_Flan.html:
--- tags: [js, web_dev] ---

Async Event Driven Programming Model

Events of all types (mouse hover, click, input text, network response) are waiting around to triggered. Events can be tied to any html element.

  • Event Type: str that specifies event (most common events)
  • Event Target: the associated object. Like, a load event is associated to window as click is to a button tag
  • Event Handler/Listener: specify how to handle event. Need to register with a event type and event target through the web browser.
  • Event Object: Contains event specific details.
  • Event Propagation: events are delineated by where they are in the DOM tree. Event rules can be made by div membership for instance.
Event Categories

Limited Survey.. Device-dependent input events Events tied to specific devices like mouse, keyboard, or touch (e.g., mousedown, mousemove, keydown, touchstart). Device-independent input events Events that represent actions regardless of input method, like click, input, and pointer events, working across mouse, keyboard, and touch. User interface events Higher-level events on form elements, such as focus, change, and submit, that represent interactions with UI components. State-change events Events triggered by browser or network changes, like load, DOMContentLoaded, online, offline, and popstate. API-specific events Events defined by specific web APIs, such as media events (playing, volumechange), IndexedDB events (success, error), or XMLHttpRequest events.

Registering Event handler Property

2 Ways of Registering

  1. (old) set a property of the document or object that is the event target. Limits one event target per each event type.
  2. (new) pass the addEventListener method of the object or element.

    3. Any object can use the addEventListener() method with the arguments event type, callback function, and an optional third argument.


<button id="mybutton">Click me</button>

<script>

let b = document.querySelector("#mybutton");

b.addEventListener("click", () => { console.log("Thanks again!"); });

</script>

Computing/web_dev/JsDefinitiveGuide_Flan.html:
--- tags:

  • js
  • web_dev

    • ---

Web Programming Basics

Javascript invented in 1994 for dynamic websites.

[!info]+ Jargon

Client-Side JavaScript

The term “client-side JavaScript” is synonymous with JavaScript written to run in a web browser; contrasted to “server-side”, runs in web servers.

And these two sides make up the endpoints of a network connection.

The <script> tag

Browsers run html. html includes <script> ... </script> tags where JavaScript is executed. The ellipsis denotes JavaScript but also defined in a script tag with the attribute src="/path/file.js". If the JavaScript scripts contain the import/export directives then the script tag that references needs the attribute type="module". Below are examples of a boolean attribute, defer and async.


<script defer src="deferred.js"></script>

<script async src="async.js"></script>

Initially, JavaScript's only method for content manipulation was document.write(), which injected HTML directly into the document's stream during the initial parsing phase. This legacy capability forces browsers to execute scripts synchronously by default, pausing all HTML parsing and rendering until the script completes, which can severely degrade page load performance. The modern way, document.querySelector(selector): Returns the first element in the document that matches the specified CSS selector. It's the go-to method for targeting a specific, unique element. By default script tags are synchronous (blocking). Both the defer and async attributes are ways of telling the browser that the linked script does not use document.write() to generate HTML output, and that the browser, therefore, can continue to parse and render the document while downloading the script. The defer attribute causes the browser to defer execution of the script until after the document has been fully loaded and parsed and is ready to be manipulated. The async attribute causes the browser to run the script as soon as possible but does not block document parsing while the script is being downloaded. If a <script> tag has both attributes, the async attribute takes precedence. - Dave Flanagan Script tags with the type="module" are by default, executed after the document has loaded, as if defer was set, but this script tag behavior can be over-written by explicitly setting async.

Loading scripts on demand

In the scenario where chunks of code is only needed if a certain action is took (button press), then these chunks can be loaded when that action is took.


// Asynchronously load and execute a script from a specified URL

// Returns a Promise that resolves when the script has loaded.

function importScript(url) {

    return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {

        let s = document.createElement("script"); // Create a <script> element

        s.onload = () => { resolve(); };          // Resolve promise when loaded

        s.onerror = (e) => { reject(e); };        // Reject on failure

        s.src = url;                              // Set the script URL

        document.head.append(s);                  // Add <script> to document

    });

}
Usage:

importScript("someScript.js")

  .then(() => { console.log("Script loaded!"); })

  .catch((err) => { console.error("Failed to load script:", err); });

[!info]+ How to Block on Render

"""Only script elements in the document's <head> can possibly block rendering. Scripts do not render-blocking by default; if a script element does not include type="module", async, or defer, then it blocks parsing, not rendering. If such a script element is added dynamically via script, you must set blocking = "render" for it to block rendering."""

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Reference/Elements/script#blocking

Parsing Versus Rendering? To Parse is to build the DOM tree internally and to Render turns them to pixels.

Document Object Model (DOM)

All valid html can be parsed in a tree. All html objects inherit from a Node parent class.


<html>

  <head>

    <title>Sample Document</title>

  </head>

  <body>

    <h1>An HTML Document</h1>

    <p>This is a <i>simple</i> document.

  </body>

</html>

The Global Object in Web Browsers

Javascript's standard library is stored in the global object. One global object per window/tab. The global object also contains web browser specific functionality accessed through the window property.

Scripts Share Namespace

Given the the three lines below are in an html file. <script src="main.js"></script> <script src="utils.js"></script> <script src="server.js"></script> Top level (scope) functions, variables, classes that are defined in main can be referenced in server without any explicit import statements. This is possible because the omission of type="module" attribute value pair in the script tag. Meaning, these three scripts share one large namespace. To scope a module namespace include type="module".

Execution of Javascript Programs

Whether an application designs it namespace with many module scopes or a single large one; they all share a global window object In Two Phases:

  1. The document content is loaded, and the code from <script> elements (both inline scripts and external scripts) is run.
    • defines call backs
  1. Async Event Driven
    • call backs are triggered on load/DOMContentLoaded like events
Client-side JavaScript threading model

Javascript is single threaded, but 'web workers' are used for concurrent behavior. This 'web worker' does NOT have access to the document content, does not share any state with the main thread or other web workers, and can can only communicate with other web workers and the main thread through async messages. This framework guarantees the concurrency is not noticed by the main thread.

Javascript Timeline
  1. A Document object is created. Element object and there text nodes are added to the tree. document.readyState is set to 'loading.'
  2. The html parser encounters script tags with no async, defer or type="module" attributes, so, default behavior is synchronous. Meaning, the script that is being sourced has the opportunity to use a document.wite() for dynamic injection. Design wise, this is place good in the execution flow to declare other call backs.
  3. The html parser encounters a script tag with a async attribute set (but not a type module). Then that scripts text begins downloading in the background because the html parser does not block execution to wait for it to load.
  4. When the document is entirely parsed document.readyState turns to 'interactive.'
  5. Any scripts with the defer tag are ran while other async tasks could be finishing up.
  6. The browser fires a “DOMContentLoaded” event on the Document object. This marks the transition from synchronous script-execution phase to the asynchronous, event-driven phase of program execution. Note, however, that there may still be async scripts that have not yet executed at this point. - D. Flanagan
  7. The document is completely parsed at this point, but the browser may still be waiting for additional content, such as images, to load. When all such content finishes loading, and when all async scripts have loaded and executed, the document.readyState property changes to “complete” and the web browser fires a “load” event on the Window object. - D. Flanagan
  8. From this point on, event handlers are invoked asynchronously in response to user input events, network events, timer expirations, and so on. - D. Flanagan
Program Errors

When a browser javascript program 'crash' and there is no catch statement, then an error message will printed to the dev console and the event loop will continue. The window object has a property onerror and this a callback function that is triggered when an uncaught error occurs. window.onunhandledrejection callback function can be set for rejected promises.

Web Security Model

Client side Javascript has limited capabilities for security reasons:

  • there is no way to write/read/delete arbitrary data to a the client computer.
  • the http requests and web sockets APIs are limited on the client side. General purpose internet clients and servers cannot be written in client side Javascript.
Same-Origin Policy

A fundamental browser security model that restricts scripts from one origin from accessing content (e.g., Document Object Model, data) from another origin. Definition of an "Origin": An origin is defined by the unique combination of the URL's:

  • Protocol: (e.g., http:// and https://)
  • Host: (e.g., www.example.com and api.example.com)
  • Port: (e.g., example.com:80 and example.com:8080)

    • A change in any of these three components results in a different origin. During development local file:// URLs are generally treated as unique, individual origins. Primary Applications:

  • DOM Access: A script in a document cannot access the properties of a document in an <iframe> if the frame's source is from a different origin.
  • Scripted HTTP Requests: JavaScript using APIs like XMLHttpRequest or fetch() cannot make requests to a different origin unless that origin explicitly permits it.

    • Execution Context:

  • The policy applies based on the origin of the document in which a script is embedded, not the origin of the script file itself.

    • A script can read only the properties of windows and documents that have the same origin as the document that contains the script. - D. Flanagan. Mechanisms for Relaxation -> document.domain Property:

  • Allows limited relaxation for pages on different subdomains of the same parent domain.
  • For example, scripts on pages from orders.example.com and catalog.example.com can both set document.domain = "example.com"; to allow mutual access.
  • This can only be set to a super domain (a domain suffix), not an unrelated domain.

    • Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS): A server-side mechanism that allows a server to explicitly whitelist origins that are permitted to make requests. With specific HTTP headers:

  • Request Header: The browser sends an Origin: header indicating the origin of the requesting script's document.
  • Response Header: The server replies with an Access-Control-Allow-Origin: header, specifying the allowed origin(s) (or * for any origin).
  • The browser enforces this policy, granting the script access to the response only if the server sends the appropriate header.
Cross-site scripting

Cross-site scripting, or XSS, is a term for a category of security issues in which an attacker injects HTML tags or scripts into a target website. Sanitizing user input is a must to combat this. Best practice to put untrusted content in an iframe and turn on the sandbox property.

Next: Events
