Computing/web_dev/JsDefinitiveGuide_Flan.html: | Category | Event Type | Description | | ------------ | ------------------ | ----------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Mouse Events | click | Fired when the user clicks an element. | | | dblclick | Fired when the user double-clicks an element. | | | mousedown | Fired when a mouse button is pressed down. | | | mouseup | Fired when a mouse button is released. | | | mousemove | Fired when the pointer is moved. | | | mouseenter | Fired when the pointer enters an element (no bubbling). | | | mouseleave | Fired when the pointer leaves an element (no bubbling). | | | mouseover | Fired when the pointer moves onto an element (bubbles). | | | mouseout | Fired when the pointer moves out of an element (bubbles). | | Keyboard | keydown | Fired when a key is pressed down. | | | keypress | Fired when a key is pressed (deprecated, use keydown/keyup). | | | keyup | Fired when a key is released. | | Form Events | input | Fired when the value of <input>, <textarea>, or <select> changes. | | | change | Fired when an element loses focus after its value was modified. | | | submit | Fired when a form is submitted. | | | focus | Fired when an element receives focus (no bubbling). | | | blur | Fired when an element loses focus (no bubbling). | | Document/Win | load | Fired when the document or resource has finished loading. | | | DOMContentLoaded | Fired when initial HTML is loaded and parsed (before images/styles). | | | resize | Fired when the window is resized. | | | scroll | Fired when the document or an element is scrolled. | | Clipboard | copy | Fired when content is copied to the clipboard. | | | cut | Fired when content is cut to the clipboard. | | | paste | Fired when content is pasted from the clipboard. | | Drag & Drop | drag | Fired while an element is being dragged. | | | dragstart | Fired when dragging starts. | | | dragend | Fired when dragging ends. | | | dragover | Fired when a dragged element is over a valid drop target. | | | drop | Fired when a dragged element is dropped on a valid target. | | Touch Events | touchstart | Fired when a finger touches the surface. | | | touchmove | Fired when a finger moves along the surface. | | | touchend | Fired when a finger is lifted off the surface. | | | touchcancel | Fired when a touch event is disrupted (e.g., OS gesture). |

Computing/web_dev/Rive/Listeners.md.html:
--- tags:

  • rive
  • web_dev
  • animation

    • ---

State Machine Events

Definitions for click, hover, and mouse actions Note, Listeners are not required for state machines

Create Listener

Animate Mode -> Listener Section panel -> plus sign

Listeners Anatomy

  1. target
  2. user action
  3. listener action
Target
  • area to listen for an action
  • can be an art board or nested art bard or object within art board
Defining an art board

While the listener is selected, select the target button and then either select the object in the hierarchy or directly on the stage. Once the defined action happens within the target area the listener will react.

Types of Targets
  • Shape or group will create a hit box
  • Art board or nested art boards will listen for any events coming from those boards

Interviewing/Behavior Questions.md.html:
--- tags: [interview] ---

[!info]- Why company 'X'? >

[!info]- What do you know about company 'X'?

[!info]- Tell me about a recent technical hurdle you faced and how did you over come it? >

[!info]+ Describe a database to me like I'm 5 years old?

A DB is a way to store things(like words and numbers) in an ordered way. Lets say we are Santa Clause and we need to keep track of which present the kids want and whether they have been good or not. So Lets think how we would store this information. We have sheet of paper of all the children in the world. This is a very long sheet of paper and it has one name on each line and above the first name there is label called "Name." Next to word

[!info]+ How would you describe the company culture and the management style? >

[!info]+ What aspect about the company surprises most new hires? >

3 things about yourself:

  1. I have an insatiable curiosity that I manage with a note taking system called Obsidian. I call it my second Brian it's where I start the store all the information that I find is valuable. In a world where we are inundated with information. It is so important to know what to keep in your active recall, what to keep in your deep memory, what to put in your notebook and what should be looked up on the spot or just in time information. I take my knowledge management system very seriously.
  1. I value human connection. Above all I try to leave situation better than I arrived at at. And this can come in many forms. I know in a business and merriment we usually have strict goals to maximize a certain metric. But when dealing with other colleagues or clients, it is important to remember we all have many things in common, even though we may seem different. We all struggle with the same human condition.
  1. I am an innate teacher. I do believe knowledge is power in the truest sense. I enjoy arming people with knowledge they need to achieve their goal goals. It is very fulfilling for me to disperse my knowledge because I know what goes around comes around and I can't wait to learn from everybody else.

---

Why do you want to work at Red Bull in Information Technology? If you were to make a list of what's important to you in a job/career, what would you write?

I want to work for Redball in information technology because information technology is where my skills lie, and I want to use them at red ball because I see red ball as an intelligent company because of their history of strategic brand/athlete alliances that keep them in the limelighte. Also, I see red bowl as a fun company I wanna be around people who are having fun who have a smile on the face but we're also working hard I know it's cliché to say but I think there's deepo= wisdom and work hard play hard.

in a career, I value growth. Personal growth, professional growth, and economic growth. I want to surround myself with intelligent, hard-working people That push me out of my comfort zone. It is important to me that I'm constantly learning, but not just technical information but learning about new interesting cultures, people and extreme sports.

---

How do you approach an activity or task that is new to you?

there are many nuances to this question. While, I do believe there are tried and true methods of achieving some goal I value the creative endeavor of seeing a new problem for the first time. Fresh eyes and fresh brains on a problem can bring wonders. New people on new tasks are not entrenched in the old way of doing things, and should allow their creativity to be unhinged. But I would like to couch those previous statements with "sometimes you do not need to reinvent the wheel."

Practically speaking when I approach new task, I will initially have a brainstorming session and jock down my initial thoughts. I'll look to company history or industry history on what has worked before and what is working now. I'll ask myself, Are there any known efficiencies and what tools do I have available? And, I would embrace the process of drafting. I'm OK with crappy first drafts. As long as I know that they are first drafts. And after my first draft I'd seek Who is the subject matter expert. Where can I read their material. The answer usually lies in copious reading.

---

Tell us about a time where you were working on a team and your team members disagreed on your approach or solution. How did you handle this situation?

I'd like to re-tell a scenario during a group porject I had in my senior Kapstone class. We agreed we wanted to build a Weather application and all mutually decided we wanted to use the language in Python. But what brought disagreement was what framework we should use. We were trying to choose between between flask and Django. A confident vocal member of my group had experience with flask, and was really pushing for it. He even had a project demonstrating Their knowledge. They spoke very persuasively. Most of the group members didn't have a strong opinion, and were willing to learn either framework, but I knew this wasn't the correct decision process just because one person had experience, but not an expert. there were four other people in the group.  I disagreed with this decision making process I knew I wasn't going to choose what technology to learn just because someone had a little experience in one. So I convinced my group on the idea that we should build an extremely simple app in both frameworks and see firsthand the the contrast. In the end we did end up going with the group members preferred choice, but for more logical reasons. We chose a framework for practicality, and not out of the whim of someone's preference.

---

Tell us about a time when you had to juggle multiple priorities. What was the situation? How did you handle it and what did you learn?

At the beginning of this academic year, I had a very full plate of responsibilities. I chose to be leader of my capstone group, I had a part-time job being a university lab assistant, I had a full load of classes, and I needed to apply for jobs. Also, my tutoring was noticed by a professor, and I was asked to present on certain topics in their class. And I couldn't shy away from this opportunity, so I accepted the increased workload because I knew it was a valuable learning experience. Most importantly, I had to leave time to recharge with my social life and exercise so I can put my best foot forward in this other areas of my life. Overall, I refined my time management skills. Assigned priority to each of the areas I described earlier and I knew each day I had to give X many hours to every task. I embraced routine. I Formalized my routine so each day I didn't have to guess on what to work on. I knew what was important. What was the next big deadline and I could spend my time working. My main Takeaway was that I can't make everything perfect but if I work hard and I can trust in my routine, I know my output is the best that I can offer and that's all I can ask for.

Founded in 2014 as a colllab of American Energy Technology Institute (GTI) & Industry-Funded R&D. First worked on material traceability the focused on in-built automation with GPS and barcode. Now a full digital construction solution from planning to build close out.

Qs: company size does it feel like a start up? culture full time after intern

--- Interview 2 with Alicia Farag and Isaiah Summers

Alicia Farag: Co-Founder and President. went to Chicago South Side Homewood-Flossmoor Community High School and to U of I for Civil engineering. also holds an MBA in Global Energy from the University of Warwick

From the Edison Electric Institute (EEI) Conference in Austin, TX 2023 The transition to electrification require the grid to be built out Alicia Farag says, "the utility companies lack high quality asset traceability" Pushing for an industry wide standard 'smart IDs' hosted on a decentralized network #### From the Grid Mod Pod with with Elizabeth Cook

  • Not only standardizing ID tag but also the material use to build out the grid.

Mutual Aid - request for material from a competitor. Streamline information exchange

Recalls and Systemic Performance Issues - failures from a certain manufacturing batch then need to know where are the affected assets

As-built monitoring

Similar Examples in other industries: baby food, meztcal

So its not about convincing companies to buy into the idea, not its about execution and being use case driven-Graham-ism

  • As Alicia said in the Edison electric conference a decentralized network of smart ID

Interviewing/technical questions/GIS.md.html:
--- tags: [gis, gis_interview] ---

[!info]- What is a GIS

High Level: A Geographic Information System is a set of computer tools that allows one to work with data that is tied a particular location on Earth.

A database with attributes that have a spatial Object tied to each record.

A GIS includes the tools for creating data, map making and analyzing the relationships

[!info]- What can a GIS be used to do?

land use planning, environmental management, sociological analysis, business marketing, city planning.

"Bartlett Map hub" examples: "Railroad Crossing Complaint Logger" ArcGIS Online map and form.

[!info]- What are the types of map data?

Discrete and Continuous

Discrete - finite or countably infinite set of values. Can be categorical or numeric. Example: Student in a class (cant have a half student) and outcomes of rolling a dice, or Land cover options.

Continuous - Can take any value within a range (real numbers). Examples: Temperature, height and weight

[!info]- What are Data Formats?

Raster and Vector

Raster - used a bit map data structure (cells in a grid approach to defining space). Ideal for continuous change across a region like land cove classification

Vector - uses XY referenced vertices and paths for discrete data ideal for governmental boundaries

TIN - Triangular Irregular Network, defines a set of adjacent triangles over a space.

Raster V. Vector:

- Vector provides more compact storage for discrete objects like for boundaries. Vector data models only store the perimeter of the entity while raster would have to store the area.

[!info]- What is map scale

Is the conversion of from a map distance to reality

[!info]- What is Resolution

refers to the sampling interval at which data is acquired.

spatial resolution - the distance interval at which the measurement was taken

temporal resolution - time interval

[!info]- What is precision

number of significant figures

[!info]- What are shapefile

developed by ESRI

vector format

consists of many files:

.dbf for stores attributes

.sbn for

.shx stores spatial extent

.shp stores location geometry

.shp.xml for meta data

.prj stores coordinate system

[!info]- What are geodatabases

types: personal, file and enterprise. Distinguished by storage. Respectively, MS Access file, folder in file system, commercial Relational Database Management System.

[!info]- What is Geographic Coordinate System?

Angular measurement from the center of the Earth

[!info]- What is Map Projection

transformation of a 3D earth model to 2D map.

Three major classes: Cylindrical (UTM), Conic (Lambert), Azimuthal (polar)

[!info]- Geo-Reference V. Geocode

geocode - given name of location coordinates are returned

geo-reference - aligns different geo information to a known GCS (through: data shifting, scaling, rotating, rectifying)

[!info]- Spatial Join

combining tables based on spatial features by containment or proximity criterion

[!info]- Overlay

viewing two feature classes at once

[!info]- Buffer

creates new zone around the proximity of a feature

[!info]- Buffer

creates new zone around the proximity of a feature

Interviewing/technical questions/Program.html:
--- tags: [programming_paradigms, declarative, imperative, oop, functional, procedural] ---

Declarative and Imperative Umbrellas

Declarative - focuses on what the program should accomplish without specifying all the steps on how to achieve the result. Examples, SQL, regular expressions, functional programming Imperative - describes step by by

Functional
  • programs constructed by applying and composing functions
  • functions are treated like 'just another data type'
  • apart of declarative
  • Haskell
Object Oriented
  • based on the idea of objects. An object contain data and methods(functions in an object) that act on data.
  • Object are created from classes. The class defines the properties (data) and the behaviors (methods)
  • great for code reuse and modularity
  • Smalltalk
Procedural
  • apart of Imperative
Interviewing/technical questions/Program.title: Programming Paradigms

Interviewing/technical questions/Python.html:
--- tags:

  • python
  • threading
  • real python

    • --- Broadly speaking, threading allows for different parts of a program to run concurrently. A thread is a separate flow of execution, meaning two things will happen at "once" (not really for most python implementations) they merely appear to happen at once. Getting python to run multiple tasks simultaneously requires a non-standard implementation or using the multi-processing library. The mainstream CPython implementation causes threads to be ineffective is some situations dues to Python's GIL that essentially limits only one thread to run at once.

What is a good candidate for threads?

Tasks that spend time waiting for external resources

What is NOT a good candidate for threads?

CPU-bound problems. Then use the multi-processing library.


import logging

import threading

import time



def thread_function(name):

    logging.info("Thread %s: starting", name)

    time.sleep(2)

    logging.info("Thread %s: finishing", name)



if __name__ == "__main__":

    format = "%(asctime)s: %(message)s"

    logging.basicConfig(format=format, level=logging.INFO,

                        datefmt="%H:%M:%S")



    logging.info("Main    : before creating thread")

    x = threading.Thread(target=thread_function, args=(1,))

    logging.info("Main    : before running thread")

    x.start()

    logging.info("Main    : wait for the thread to finish")

    # x.join()

    logging.info("Main    : all done")





$ ./single_thread.py

Main    : before creating thread

Main    : before running thread

Thread 1: starting

Main    : wait for the thread to finish

Main    : all done

Thread 1: finishing

In python a daemon thread is a type of thread that will shut down immediately after the program exits. If a program is running threads that are not daemons then the program will wait for those to finish before terminating the program.

--- Source - Real Python
Interviewing/technical questions/Python.title: Python Threading

Interviewing/technical questions/Python'.html:
--- tags:

  • python
  • GIL
  • global interpreter lock

    • ---

Global Interpreter Lock (GIL)

The GIL is a mutex (lock) that only allows one thread to hold control of the python interpreter.

When CPython started to support multiple operating system threads, it became necessary to protect various CPython internal data structures from concurrent access. Instead of adding lock or using atomic operations to protect the correctness of for instance reference counting, the content of lists, dictionaries, or internal data structures. The CPython developers decided to take a simpler approach and use a single global lock, the GIL, to protect all of these data structures from incorrect concurrent accesses. One can start multiple threads in CPython but the byte code runs one thread at a time.
Interviewing/technical questions/Python'.title: Python'S Gil

Interviewing/what i know.md.html: I used the C/C++ programming language in courses to understand low level system concepts like processes and threads. I was introduced to the consumer producer design pattern where I implemented mutually exclusive locks on shared resources to ensure safe thread synchronization. In similar classes we translated simple programs from C to assembly and vice versa. With Java i was taught data structures. Learning fundamental algorithms like merge sort and depth first search. I learned how to analyze algorithms and how the space-time tradeoff when considering performance. Java was used in my design patterns class where I was introduced how to make a code base's functionality grow without unneeded complexities. In my '[Programming] Language Concepts' we use Scheme and Scala to learned ideas that are implemented in all languages like scope, types, and expressions. Python was used in my spatial data science course. I used open source geo-spatial libraries to scrape, clean, analyze and visualize US census data. Also with python I learned socket programming in distributed systems class where I built a terminal based messenger app they can send files. In my free time, I took it upon myself to explore shell scripting where I became familiar with bash and zsh. I did a small project in zsh that retrieves a website's HTML and parses is it for specific data with regular expressions. Also, I learned the Dart the language using the flutter framework to created a simple portfolio website hosted for free on Github.

.mermaid-toolbar-element:hover { background-color: var(--interactive-hover); }
.mermaid-tools-element-category-header::before { content: "▼  "; font-size: 70%; padding-bottom: 2px; }
.mermaid-tools-element-category-header.collapsed::before { content: "▶  "; font-size: 70%; padding-bottom: 2px; }
.mermaid-tools-element-container { padding-top: 6px; border-bottom: var(--border-width) solid var(--color-base-35); }
.mermaid-tools-edit-element-modal > div { margin-bottom: 0.5rem; }
.mermaid-tools-edit-element-modal label { margin-right: 1rem; }
button.run-code-button { display: none; color: var(--text-muted); position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: 0px; margin: 5px; padding: 5px 20px; z-index: 100; }
button.clear-button { display: none; color: var(--text-muted); position: absolute; bottom: 0px; left: 0px; margin: 5px; padding: 5px 20px; z-index: 100; }
pre:hover .run-code-button, pre:hover .clear-button { display: block; }
pre:hover .run-button-disabled, pre:hover .clear-button-disabled { display: none; }
.run-button-disabled, .clear-button-disabled { display: none; }
pre:hover code.language-output { margin-bottom: 28px; }
:not(.use-custom-output-color) code.language-output span.stdout { color: var(--text-muted)  !important; }
.use-custom-output-color code.language-output span.stdout { color: var(--code-output-text-color)  !important; }
:not(.use-custom-error-color) code.language-output span.stderr { color: red !important; }
.use-custom-error-color code.language-output span.stderr { color: var(--code-error-text-color)  !important; }
code.language-output hr { margin: 0px 0px 1em; }
.settings-code-input-box textarea, .settings-code-input-box input { min-width: 400px; min-height: 100px; font-family: monospace; resize: vertical; }
input.interactive-stdin { font: inherit; }
.manage-executors-view h3 { margin: 1em; }
.manage-executors-view ul { margin: 1em; padding: 0px; list-style-type: none; }
.manage-executors-view ul li { padding: 0.5em; background: var(--background-primary-alt); border-radius: 4px; display: grid; flex-direction: column; margin-bottom: 0.5em; }
.manage-executors-view small { text-transform: uppercase; font-weight: bold; letter-spacing: 0.1ch; grid-row: 1 / auto; }
.manage-executors-view .filename { grid-row: 2 / auto; }
.manage-executors-view li button { grid-area: 1 / 2 / 3 / auto; margin: 0px; padding: 0.25em; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center; color: var(--text-muted); background: none; }
.manage-executors-view li button:hover { background: var(--background-tertiary); color: var(--icon-color-hover); }
.manage-executors-view > div { position: relative; }
.manage-executors-view .empty-state { color: var(--text-muted); padding: 0.5em; }
.has-run-code-button { position: relative; }
.has-run-code-button pre { z-index: 1; }
.load-state-indicator { position: absolute; top: 0.1em; left: -2em; width: 2em; height: 2em; background: var(--background-primary-alt); border-top-left-radius: 4px; border-bottom-left-radius: 4px; color: var(--tx1); transform: translateX(2em); transition: transform 0.25s ease 0s, opacity 0.25s ease 0s; opacity: 0; pointer-events: none; cursor: pointer; }
.load-state-indicator svg { width: 1.5em; height: 1.5em; margin: 0.25em; }
.load-state-indicator.visible { transform: translateX(var(--folding-offset, 0)); opacity: 1; pointer-events: all; }
.load-state-indicator::before { content: ""; box-shadow: -1em 0 1em -0.75em inset var(--background-modifier-box-shadow); position: absolute; display: block; width: 100%; height: 100%; transform: translateX(-2em); opacity: 0; transition: transform 0.25s ease 0s, opacity 0.25s ease 0s; pointer-events: none; }
.load-state-indicator.visible::before { transform: translateX(0px); opacity: 1; }

table { border-collapse: collapse; border: 1px solid var(--background-secondary)  !important; }
thead { border-bottom: 2px solid var(--background-modifier-border)  !important; }
th { font-weight: 600 !important; border: 1px solid var(--background-secondary)  !important; }
td { border-left: 1px solid var(--background-secondary)  !important; border-right: 1px solid var(--background-secondary)  !important; border-bottom: 1px solid var(--background-secondary)  !important; }
.markdown-rendered tbody tr:nth-child(2n) { background-color: var(--table-row-even-background)  !important; }
.markdown-rendered tbody tr:nth-child(2n+1) { background-color: var(--table-row-odd-background)  !important; }
.markdown-rendered tbody tr:nth-child(2n):hover, .markdown-rendered tbody tr:nth-child(2n+1):hover { background-color: var(--table-row-background-hover)  !important; }
.markdown-rendered mark { background-color: var(--text-highlight-bg); color: var(--text-highlight-fg); }
.markdown-rendered mark a { font-weight: 600; color: var(--red)  !important; }
.search-result-file-matched-text { color: var(--text-highlight-fg)  !important; }
.cm-hashtag-begin:hover, .cm-hashtag-end:hover { color: var(--text-accent); text-decoration: underline; }
input[type="checkbox"] { border: 1px solid var(--checkbox-color); }
input[type="checkbox"]:checked { background-color: var(--checkbox-color); box-shadow: inset 0 0 0 2px var(--background-primary); }
input[type="checkbox"]:checked::after { display: none; }
code[class*="language-"], pre[class*="language-"] { line-height: var(--line-height-tight)  !important; }
.cm-url { color: var(--link-url)  !important; }
.cm-url:hover { color: var(--text-accent-color)  !important; }
.cm-highlight { color: var(--text-highlight-fg)  !important; }
.cm-inline-code { border-radius: var(--radius-s); font-size: var(--code-size); padding: 0.1em 0.25em; }
.cm-line .cm-strong { color: var(--bold-color)  !important; }
.mermaid .note { fill: var(--mermaid-note)  !important; }
.mermaid .actor { fill: var(--mermaid-actor)  !important; }
.mermaid .loopLine { stroke: var(--mermaid-loopline)  !important; }
.mermaid .loopText > tspan, .mermaid .entityLabel { fill: var(--neutral-red)  !important; }
.mermaid .exclude-range { fill: var(--mermaid-exclude)  !important; }
.mermaid .sequenceNumber { fill: var(--mermaid-seqnum)  !important; }
.calendar .week-num { color: var(--calendar-week)  !important; }
.calendar .today { color: var(--calendar-today)  !important; }
.calendar .week-num:hover, .calendar .day:hover { color: var(--calendar-hover)  !important; background-color: var(--calendar-background-hover)  !important; }
.markdown-embed-title { color: var(--yellow); font-weight: 600 !important; }
.cm-active { background-color: var(--cursor-line-background)  !important; }
.nav-file-tag { color: var(--nav-file-tag)  !important; }
.is-flashing { background-color: var(--flashing-background)  !important; }
.dataview.inline-field-key { border-top-left-radius: var(--radius-s); border-bottom-left-radius: var(--radius-s); padding-left: 4px; font-family: var(--font-monospace); font-size: var(--font-smaller); color: var(--dataview-key)  !important; background-color: var(--dataview-key-background)  !important; }
.dataview.inline-field-value { border-top-right-radius: var(--radius-s); border-bottom-right-radius: var(--radius-s); padding-right: 4px; font-family: var(--font-monospace); font-size: var(--font-smaller); color: var(--dataview-value)  !important; background-color: var(--dataview-value-background)  !important; }
.suggestion-highlight { color: var(--bright-red); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 { font-family: var(--font-mermaid); font-size: 16px; fill: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .error-icon { fill: var(--background-primary); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .error-text { fill: var(--text-error); stroke: var(--text-error); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .edge-thickness-normal { stroke-width: 2px; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .edge-thickness-thick { stroke-width: 3.5px; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .edge-pattern-solid { stroke-dasharray: 0; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .edge-pattern-dashed { stroke-dasharray: 3; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .edge-pattern-dotted { stroke-dasharray: 2; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .marker { fill: var(--text-normal); stroke: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .marker.cross { stroke: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 svg { font-family: var(--font-mermaid); font-size: 16px; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .label { font-family: var(--font-mermaid); color: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .cluster-label text { fill: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .cluster-label span { color: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .label text, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 span { fill: var(--text-normal); color: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node rect, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node circle, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node ellipse, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node polygon, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node path { fill: var(--background-primary); stroke: var(--text-muted); stroke-width: 1px; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node .label { text-align: center; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node.clickable { cursor: pointer; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .arrowheadPath { }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .edgePath .path { stroke: var(--text-normal); stroke-width: 2px; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .flowchart-link { stroke: var(--text-normal); fill: none; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .edgeLabel { background-color: var(--background-secondary); text-align: center; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .edgeLabel rect { opacity: 0.5; background-color: var(--background-secondary); fill: var(--background-secondary); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .cluster rect { fill: rgb(247, 249, 255); stroke: rgb(207, 219, 243); stroke-width: 1px; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .cluster text { fill: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .cluster span { color: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 div.mermaidTooltip { position: absolute; text-align: center; max-width: 200px; padding: 2px; font-family: var(--font-mermaid); font-size: 12px; background: var(--background-secondary-alt); border-radius: 2px; pointer-events: none; z-index: 100; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .flowchartTitleText { text-anchor: middle; font-size: 18px; fill: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 foreignobject { overflow: visible; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 #arrowhead, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 #sequencenumber, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .cluster text, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .label text, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 text, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 text.actor { fill: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 line { stroke: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 g > g > circle, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 g > g > path { stroke: var(--background-accent); color: var(--text-normal); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .label rect { display: none; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .cluster rect { stroke-width: 1px; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node circle, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node ellipse, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node path, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node polygon, #mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node rect { fill: var(--background-secondary-alt); stroke: var(--background-modifier-border); stroke-width: 1px; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node .label { text-align: center; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .node.clickable { cursor: pointer; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .arrowheadPath { fill: var(--text-muted); }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .edgePath .path { stroke: var(--text-muted); stroke-width: 1.5px; }
#mermaid-toolbar-element-Flowchart-0 .edgeLabel { background-color: var(--background-primary); text-align: center; }

fract.html.html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <style>
    body {
      margin: 0;
      overflow: hidden;
    }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <canvas id="fractalCanvas"></canvas>
  <script>
    const canvas = document.getElementById("fractalCanvas");
    canvas.width = window.innerWidth;
    canvas.height = window.innerHeight;
    
    const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

    const maxIterations = 1000;
    const magnification = 300;
    const offsetX = canvas.width / 2;
    const offsetY = canvas.height / 2;

    function isInMandelbrotSet(x, y) {
      let real = 0;
      let imaginary = 0;

      for (let i = 0; i < maxIterations; i++) {
        const realTemp = real * real - imaginary * imaginary + x;
        const imaginaryTemp = 2 * real * imaginary + y;

        real = realTemp;
        imaginary = imaginaryTemp;

        if (real * real + imaginary * imaginary > 4) {
          return i / maxIterations * 255;
        }
      }

      return 0;
    }

    for (let x = 0; x < canvas.width; x++) {
      for (let y = 0; y < canvas.height; y++) {
        const real = (x - offsetX) / magnification;
        const imaginary = (y - offsetY) / magnification;

        const colorValue = isInMandelbrotSet(real, imaginary);
        ctx.fillStyle = `rgb(${colorValue}, ${colorValue}, ${colorValue})`;
        ctx.fillRect(x, y, 1, 1);
      }
    }
  </script>
</body>
</html>

frcolor.html.html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <style>
    body {
      margin: 0;
      overflow: hidden;
    }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <canvas id="fractalCanvas"></canvas>
  <script>
    const canvas = document.getElementById("fractalCanvas");
    canvas.width = window.innerWidth;
    canvas.height = window.innerHeight;
    
    const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

    const maxIterations = 1000;
    const magnification = 300;
    const offsetX = canvas.width / 2;
    const offsetY = canvas.height / 2;

    function getColor(iterations) {
      const hue = (iterations / maxIterations) * 360;
      return `hsl(${hue}, 100%, 50%)`;
    }

    function isInMandelbrotSet(x, y) {
      let real = 0;
      let imaginary = 0;

      for (let i = 0; i < maxIterations; i++) {
        const realTemp = real * real - imaginary * imaginary + x;
        const imaginaryTemp = 2 * real * imaginary + y;

        real = realTemp;
        imaginary = imaginaryTemp;

        if (real * real + imaginary * imaginary > 4) {
          return i;
        }
      }

      return maxIterations;
    }

    for (let x = 0; x < canvas.width; x++) {
      for (let y = 0; y < canvas.height; y++) {
        const real = (x - offsetX) / magnification;
        const imaginary = (y - offsetY) / magnification;

        const iterations = isInMandelbrotSet(real, imaginary);
        const color = getColor(iterations);
        
        ctx.fillStyle = color;
        ctx.fillRect(x, y, 1, 1);
      }
    }
  </script>
</body>
</html>
